questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with B/L hilar lymphadenopathy without any significant lung parenchymal involvement. Her chest X-ray shows symmetric mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy in a "1-2-3" pattern. What is the most likely stage of sarcoidosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Staging of Sarcoidosis

Stage 0

No visible abnormalities

Stage 1

Hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy without lung parenchymal changes (Option B)

Stage 2

Hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy with lung disease (Option C)

Stage 3

Diffuse lung disease without lymphadenopathy (Option D)

Stage 4

End-stage fibrosis (Option A)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. X-ray chest is performed, revealing an air bronchogram. Which of the following conditions is characterized by the absence of air bronchograms?

A 45-year-old male presents with a chronic cough and mild chest discomfort. A chest X-ray reveals a mediastinal mass with well-defined margins and a paravertebral location, suggestive of a lesion arising from neural tissue. To confirm the diagnosis and further evaluate the mass, the physician orders additional imaging. What is the most appropriate imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: CT scan of the chest with contrast

questions.explanation:
Compartment

Boundaries

Common Masses/Abnormalities

Anterior (Prevascular)

Posterior sternum to anterior heart and great vessels
  • Thymic masses: Thymoma, thymic hyperplasia, thymic carcinoma
  • Germ cell tumors: Teratoma
  • Thyroid masses: Ectopic thyroid, substernal goiter
  • Lymphoma: Hodgkin's, non-Hodgkin's

Middle (Visceral)

Between anterior and posterior compartments

Contains heart, great vessels, trachea, esophagus, lymph nodes
  • Bronchogenic cysts
  • Pericardial cysts
  • Lymphadenopathy (metastasis, lymphoma, sarcoidosis)
  • Aortic aneurysms, vascular abnormalities

Posterior (Paravertebral)

Posterior heart and great vessels to anterior vertebrae
  • Neurogenic tumors: Schwannomas, neurofibromas, ganglioneuromas
  • Esophageal lesions: Tumors, diverticula
  • Spinal abnormalities: Vertebral infections, hernias, masses

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with drooping of the right eyelid, a constricted right pupil, and lack of sweating on the right side of his face. He also reports weakness, pain, and numbness in his right arm. Chest x-ray reports an apical lung mass on the right side. What is the imaging modality of choice to identify the underlying cause of his symptoms?

A 60-year-old man with a history of working as a shipyard worker presents with progressive dyspnea, a persistent dry cough, and chest tightness. He also reports recent weight loss and has experienced crackles upon auscultation. A CT scan of the chest reveals a distinct structure. What could be the underlying mechanism responsible for the observed sign on the CT image?

options.label: A
options.text: Round atelectasis causing a distinct pattern of lung collapse.

options.label: B
options.text: Calcified pleural plaques resulting in alterations in the pleural surface.

options.label: C
options.text: A large nodule surrounded by small nodules indicating a significant inflammatory process.

options.label: D
options.text: Interstitial fibrosis leading to a reticular pattern affecting lung architecture.

questions.correct_answer: A. Round atelectasis causing a distinct pattern of lung collapse.
questions.explanation:
Sign/Condition

Features

Pleural Plaques

Holly Leaf Sign: Calcified pleural plaques, exhibiting irregular, thickened nodular edges that resemble the shape of a holly leaf.

Mesothelioma

Radiological Feature: Irregular thickening of the pleura, often involving the mediastinal pleura, leading to fibrothorax/ frozen.

Comet Tail Sign (Crow's Feet Sign)

Mechanism: Localized atelectasis with adjacent blood vessels and bronchi drawn towards the collapsed area.

Appearance: Rounded opacity with curving vessels or bronchi radiating from it, resembling a comet’s tail or crow’s feet, visible on CT.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea, a dry cough, and weight loss over the past six months. On examination, clubbing of the fingers is noted. A chest CT scan reveals a predominantly subpleural reticular pattern with areas of honeycombing predominantly affecting the lower lobes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP)

Non-Specific Interstitial Pneumonia (NSIP) (Option A)
  • It presents as a mainly subpleural bibasal reticular pattern with areas of honeycomb (subpleural cystic airspaces with discrete, thickened walls that are stacked or lined up in a row) destruction.
  • As the disease advances, it tends to spread along the lung periphery, affecting the anterior parts of the upper lobes, referred to as the 'propeller blade distribution.'
  • There are signs of traction bronchiectasis and bronchiolectasis.
  • Ground-glass opacities are not predominant.
  • Bilateral ground-glass opacities accompanied by fine reticular patterns.
  • Primarily peripheral in distribution, but may also appear patchy or band-like.
  • Minimal or absent honeycomb pattern.
  • Presence of traction bronchiectasis and bronchiolectasis.
  • Subpleural sparing is seen.

questions.text: The most common HRCT finding in a patient with COVID-19 is:
Popcorn calcification in lung is seen in:
A 28-year-old shepherd presents with chronic cough and occasional hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following radiological signs is most likely represented in this image?
questions.explanation:
Lung abscess

Hydatid cyst

Hydropneumothorax

 

Cavity filled with air & fluid

  

Water lily sign (partially fluid-filled cyst with a floating endocyst)

  

An air fluid level in the pleural space

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with fever, cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss over the past month. X-ray chest is taken and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Infections

Neoplastic

Cardiac

Miscellaneous

  • Tuberculosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Coccidioidomycosis
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia
  • Nocardiosis
  • Bronchoalveolar carcinoma
  • Carcinoma lung with lymphangitis carcinomatosa
  • Metastatic carcinoma

Hemosiderosis in long standing condition, rheumatic heart disease, mitral stenosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Silicosis
  • Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Drug-induced interstitial lung disease (e.g., methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, nitrofurantoin)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, and weight loss. The chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 62-year-old male with a history of smoking presents to the emergency department with increased shortness of breath and fever. A chest X-ray is performed, as shown below. Which of the following radiological signs is seen in this case?
questions.explanation:
Direct Signs

Indirect Signs

  1. Loss of aeration
  2. Displacement of fissures (most reliable and earliest sign)
  3. Crowding of pulmonary vessels and bronchi
  4. Hilar elevation on PA view: Sign of upper lobe collapse
  5. Hilar depression: Sign of lower lobe collapse
  1. Compensatory hyperinflation in adjacent lobes
  2. Mediastinal shift
  3. Vascular reorientation
  4. Tracheal shift
  5. Cardiac outline displacement
  6. Hemidiaphragm elevation
  7. Juxtaphrenic peak of diaphragm: Indicate upper lobe collapse
  8. Rib crowding
  9. Hilar displacement

questions.text: Match the following: Disease Radiologic Finding A) Klebsiella Pneumonia 1) Reticular Shadows B) Aspergilloma 2) Air Bronchogram C) Staphylococcal Pneumonia 3) Bulging Fissure Sign D) Acute Epiglottitis 4) Air-Crescent Sign E) Pneumocystis carinii Pneumonia 5) Thumb Sign
A 45-year-old male presents with a cough, dyspnea, and fever. A chest radiograph shows loss of the right heart border. Which lung area is most likely affected?
A medical student is learning to identify anterior and posterior ribs on a PA chest X-ray. Identify the labeled rib shown below:

A 10-year-old child is brought to the emergency by her father after she accidentally swallowed a coin while playing. Her chest X-ray reveals the following findings: Identify the location of the foreign body.
questions.explanation:
Coin in esophagus

Coin in trachea

  • Detected using a chest X-ray, the following findings may be noted:
    • The coin is arranged in the coronal plane of the esophagus. (Option A)
    • The most common site of impaction is at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle.
    • Appears round on the frontal (posteroanterior) view.
    • It appears tangentially in the lateral view.
  • Chest x-ray findings:
    • The coin is arranged in a sagittal plane.
    • It appears tangentially in a frontal/PA view.
    • Appears en face in lateral radiographs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic productive cough and recurrent episodes of foul-smelling sputum and hemoptysis. A high-resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest is shown below. Which of the following radiological signs is most characteristic of the condition seen in this image?

A 30-year-old female presents with sudden-onset chest pain and difficulty breathing after a recent blunt trauma to the chest. Chest CT is taken and is shown below. Which of the following radiological findings is not typically seen in this case?
A 68-year-old male patient presents with cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain. A contrast CT is taken and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Image

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient with a history of congestive heart failure presents with worsening shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. A chest X-ray PA view is taken, which is shown below. Which of the following statements about the finding on the chest X-ray is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is most commonly with effusion occupying the oblique fissure.

options.label: B
options.text: It may be mistaken for a lung mass due to its appearance.

options.label: C
options.text: It will typically require surgical intervention to resolve.

options.label: D
options.text: It is always associated with exudative pleural effusion.

questions.correct_answer: B. It may be mistaken for a lung mass due to its appearance.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of COPD presents with a 2-week history of increasing shortness of breath and a persistent cough. On examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the left, and a chest X-ray is taken, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient with a large tension pneumothorax after experiencing a fall is being examined with ultrasound. Which of the following findings will be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ultrasound findings in pneumothorax

Pleural stripe (Option C)

The echogenic line known as the 'pleural stripe' reflects most of the acoustic energy at the air-pleural interface and is the normal pleura.

Artefacts

  • Vertical echogenic bands called 'comet tails' are absent in pneumothorax.
  • 'A lines' are horizontal reverberation artefacts caused by reflection from the pleura in the presence of pneumothorax.

Lung sliding (Option A)
  • It is a normal finding seen due to the shimmering of the pleural stripe at the pleural surface.
  • This sign disappears in pneumothorax.

Lung point sign 
  • Indicates the border between sliding lung and pneumothorax which helps assess size.

Barcode/ stratosphere sign
  • In cases where lung sliding is absent, M-mode images show uniform horizontal straight lines known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign.
  • This is seen in pneumothorax.
  • Normal lung shows Sea-shore sign (Option B).

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency after a fall from a tree. He developed shortness of breath and chest pain, is tachypneic, and has distended neck veins on examination. His chest X-ray shows as follows: Which of the following is the correct finding here?
questions.explanation:
Tension Pneumothorax

  • Significant contralateral deviation of the mediastinum (vs Option A)
  • Collapsed lung
  • Depression of ipsilateral hemidiaphragm (vs Option B)

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with the following anomalies of chest and hands. He has a history of having these anomalies since childhood but has no other symptoms. His chest X-ray shows a left hyperlucent lobe. Which other condition can show a similar chest X-ray picture?
questions.explanation:
Whiteout hemithorax/Opacified hemithorax

Blackout hemithorax/Hyperlucent hemithorax

Differential diagnoses

Differential diagnoses

  • Atelectasis of the entire lung (Option A)
  • Large pleural effusion (Option D)
  • Pneumonia of the entire lung
  • Postpneumonectomy appearance
  • Large pulmonary, pleural, or chest wall mass like Ewing sarcoma, mesothelioma
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia or agenesis (Option B)
  • Radiologic technique errors
  • Emphysema (bullous emphysema)
  • Asymmetric chest wall soft tissue due to conditions like:
    • Poland syndrome
    • Unilateral mastectomy
    • Some professions like butchers, carpenters, etc
  • Atrophy of trapezius muscle after radical neck dissection
  • Extrapulmonary air collection in pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema
  • Contralateral large pleural effusion (Pseudo hyperlucent appearance of opposite lung)
  • Bronchial obstruction
    • Foreign body in children
    • Bronchial atresia
    • Endobronchial tumor
    • Broncholith
  • Bronchiolitis obliterans in Swyer-James syndrome
  • Congenital lobar hyperinflation
  • Conditions affecting pulmonary vessels:
    • Pulmonary agenesis or hypoplasia
    • Proximal interruption of pulmonary artery
    • Massive central pulmonary embolism (PE) leading to oligemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with significant facial swelling, prominent neck veins, and difficulty breathing. These findings suggest an obstruction in the venous return from the head, neck, and upper limbs. A CT scan is conducted to assess the cause of these symptoms. In the diagram provided below, which of the following structures is most likely obstructed, leading to the clinical presentation observed in this patient?
In a lateral chest X-ray, which area should you focus on to identify pathology in the hilar region?
questions.explanation:
Right Lung

Left Lung

Three lobes: Upper, Middle, Lower

Two lobes: Upper, Lower

Fissures:

Horizontal fissure: Separates the upper and middle lobes.

Oblique fissure: Separates the middle from the lower lobe, and also divides the upper from the lower lobe.

Fissures:

Oblique (major) fissure: Separates the upper from the lower lobe.

Elevated Hemidiaphragm

Flat Hemidiaphragm

One side of the diaphragm appears higher than normal.

The normally dome-shaped diaphragm appears flattened and lower in position.

Causes:

 
  • Subphrenic Abscess: Pus beneath diaphragm.
  • Hepatomegaly/Splenomegaly: Enlarged organs push the diaphragm upward.
  • Diaphragmatic Palsy: Paralysis due to phrenic nerve injury.
  • Lung Collapse/Fibrosis: Loss of lung volume elevates the diaphragm.
  • Atelectasis: Collapsed lung leads to diaphragm elevation.

Causes:

 
  • COPD: Hyperinflated lungs cause a flat diaphragm and tubular heart appearance.
  • Tension Pneumothorax: Air pushes the diaphragm downward.
  • Emphysema: Destruction of lung tissue results in diaphragm flattening.

questions.text: Non-clinical question Match the following chest pathologies and their corresponding imaging modalities. Chest Pathology Imaging Modality of Choice 1. Aortic aneurysm a. MRI 2. Pneumonia b. Ultrasound 3. Pleural Effusion c. CECT 4. Posterior mediastinal mass d. Chest X-ray
questions.explanation:
Chest Pathology

I-Imaging Modality of Choice

1. Aortic aneurysm

c. CECT

2. Pneumonia

d. Chest X-ray

3. Pleural Effusion

b. Ultrasound

4. Posterior mediastinal mass

a. MRI

questions.text: A 25-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident was stabilized in the field with needle decompression for severe shortness of breath, decreased breath sounds, and hyper-resonance on the right side of the chest. Upon arrival at the emergency department, he is hemodynamically stable. Which chest X-ray view is most appropriate to confirm the underlying condition?
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Normal Lung

Pneumothorax

Inspiration

Black

Black

Expiration

White

Black
